ngiemboon: Atsɔ́ lyɛ̌ʼ láʼ ńgwɔ́, etsɔ́ mbàŋa tsɛ̀ɛ láʼ pâ mezwě pɔ́b pú ńgyáŋa lóŋ tɛʼ, ńtí mefɛ̌ pɔ́b pà Yúndà.
en: There was a widespread outcry from the people and their wives against their Jewish countrymen.

ngiemboon: Etsɔ́ pʉ̀a ne ńgɔɔn ngie: «Peg lâ gubé yég yembàŋa tà mbɔɔ yepanzwě gyɔ́ɔn. Peg ne ńkwoŋo légẅiin ngesáŋ ntsíŋ, ḿpfɛ́ tá ńdɔg ńgwɔ́ wó.»
en: Some were saying, “We, our sons, and our daughters are numerous. Let us get grain so that we can eat and live.”

ngiemboon: Petsɔ́ pʉ̀a ne ńgɔɔn yɔ́b ngie: «Peg gẅiin léná menkáʼ még na jÿɔ́ʼ, pâ metÿǒ melùʼ, mbɔɔ mendá még, tá ńdɔg ńgẅiin ngesáŋ ntsíŋ gie peg ge lɔg lÿɔ́ʼɔ cÿó.»
en: Others were saying, “We are mortgaging our fields, vineyards, and homes to get grain during the famine.”

ngiemboon: Petsɔ́ pʉ̀a ne ńgɔɔn yɔ́b ngie: Peg ka lɔg menkáʼ még pâ metÿǒ melùʼ, mbɔɔ mendá még fú nkáb tá ńdɔg ḿbéen ncùb mbwó fùɔ.
en: Still others were saying, “We have borrowed money to pay the king’s tax   on our fields and vineyards.  # 5:2–4 Dt 15:7–8

ngiemboon: Tá mbà mbab nnɛ́ yege pâ ye mefɛ̌ pégè gwɔ́ pɔ́ tàʼa mmó! Egubé yég yembàŋa pâ yɔ́b gwɔ́ pɔ́ tàʼa mmó! Peg ge lɔg gubé yég yepanzwě mbɔɔ yembàŋa gÿo menkwɔɔn; lelÿò gubé yég yepanzwě kéen ńzɔɔn ńdáʼ ńcʉ́ʼ menkwɔɔn, peg cʉ́ʼ patemmó, menkáʼ még pâ metÿǒ melùʼ cʉ́ʼ shúm pʉ̀a mendyɛ̀ʼɛ.
en: We and our children are just like our countrymen and their children, yet we are subjecting our sons and daughters to slavery.   Some of our daughters are already enslaved,  # 5:5 Ex 21:7–11 but we are powerless  # 5:5 Lit but there is not the power in our hand because our fields and vineyards belong to others.”

ngiemboon: Anò la gyáŋa wɔ́ɔn tɛʼ fʉ̀ʼ gie n da júʼ páʼ pɔ́ ne shwóŋo meshwóŋè amɛ̌.
en: I became extremely angry   when I heard their outcry and these complaints.

ngiemboon: N záb ngie ngwɔ́ n dɔgɔ nò ńdaʼ mekěm mbɔɔ pasáʼntsaŋ, ńgɔɔn né pɔ́b ngie: Áa kɔ́ gí! Pi fu nkáb né mefɛ̌ pí ńnéŋe pì mǒ! Mèŋ n da gÿo púʼu ńtóŋo máamáa cúʼtè ńtíi wɔ́b.
en: After seriously considering the matter, I accused the nobles and officials, saying to them, “Each of you is charging his countrymen interest.”   So I called a large assembly against them

ngiemboon: Ńgɔɔn mbwó pɔ́b ngie: «Á gʉa na peg, mbà peg ka lɔg yeg nkáb gie peg ka gẅiin, ńcuʼ mefɛ̌ pég pà Yúndà pie mé la sẅiŋe mbwó patezsě Ssé. Á gʉa na pi mbà pi ge gÿo sẅiŋ mefɛ̌ pi, é piŋ sẅiŋe wɔ́b pɔ́ mbwó peg!»
en: and said, “We have done our best to buy back our Jewish countrymen who were sold to foreigners, but now you sell your own countrymen, and we have to buy them back.”   They remained silent and could not say a word.  # 5:8 Jr 8:9

ngiemboon: Mèŋ n gíŋe ńgɔɔn ngie: «Ammó gie pi gÿǒ kaa poŋo! Tà á kɔʼɔ́ te ne ńzɛ́te ngie pi néŋe ḿbɔ́g Ssé yege, ńdɔg ḿbɔ́ɔn páʼ ngwɔ́ patezsě Ssé cʉa na megàŋmbù pégè ńzoonte wégè wɔ́?
en: Then I said, “What you are doing isn’t right. Shouldn’t you walk in the fear of our God   and not invite the reproach of our foreign enemies?  # 5:9 2Sm 12:14; Neh 4:4

ngiemboon: Mèŋ yɔ́ɔn, ńgÿo mefɛ̌ pɔ́ɔn mbɔɔ megàŋafàʼ pɔ́ɔn, ka fu nkáb mbɔɔ ngesáŋ ntsíŋ yege ńná né pɔ́b. Mèŋ n sẅíŋte gẅí ngie pege nyé yɛ̌ njǔ né pɔ́b!
en: Even I, as well as my brothers and my servants, have been lending them money and grain. Please, let’s stop charging this interest.

ngiemboon: N gíŋe ńkẅiʼi sẅíŋte gẅí lyɛ̌ʼɔɔn ngie pi pú ńtsɔ́ʼ shúm ŋwɛ́ ńná né pɔ́b, mbɔɔ menkáʼ mɔ́b, lâ metÿǒ melùʼ, mbɔɔ metÿǒ mevɛ́ olive, ḿbéle mendá mɔ́b mǒ, ńgʉa ńná ngesáŋ ntsíŋ yɔb mbɔɔ melùʼ lâ mevɛ́, mbɔɔ nkáb gie pi ka fuu mbwó pɔ́b té zɛ́te wɔ́b pì.»
en: Return their fields, vineyards, olive groves, and houses to them immediately, along with the percentage   of the money, grain, new wine, and fresh oil  # 5:11 Neh 10:37 that you have been assessing them.”

ngiemboon: Pɔ́ tsɔ́ʼ ngie: «Peg ge tsɔ́ʼɔ kɔ̀ɔkɔ́ɔ é ná né pɔ́b té zɔɔn ńgíŋe ńzɛ́te wɔ́b tsɔ́ mmó; peg ge gÿo mmó gie ɔ̀ zɛté. N deen ńké ńtóŋ panuŋepwɔʼ, pɔ́ tyé mvfò pɔ́b ńkʉa ngie pɔ́ te kúbe nò gie pɔ́ ka gɔɔn wɔ́.»
en: They responded, “We will return these things and require nothing more from them.   We will do as you say.”

ngiemboon: Mèŋ n deen ńké ńkẅile púɔ pɔ̀ɔn nzsǒ fÿág yɔ̀ɔn, ńcʉʼte ńgɔɔn ngie: «Á poŋ ngie Ssé gíŋe ńcʉʼte pʉ̀a metsèm pie é gɔɔn nò, pɔ́ té tÿɔ́gɔ kwò mǒ wɔ́, pɔ́ páʼ n cʉʼte múɔ pɔ̀ɔn wɔ̀ɔn. Á poŋ ngie mé fó mbwó pɔ́b ńkẅé tsìŋendá yɔ́b mbɔɔ shúm sie pɔ́ gẅiin tà pɔ́ cʉ́ʼ ńtyé pɔ́ mbwó mesẅɛ̀ɛ.» Anùɔ láʼ la pú ńzẅɛ ńgɔɔn ngie: «Oon, á gwɔ́ pɔ́ púʼu, pɔ́ metsèm leen ńké ńzɔb ntse ńdɔg ńguʼte Cʉ̀apʉ̀a!»
en: I also shook the folds of my robe and said, “May God likewise shake from his house and property everyone who doesn’t keep this promise. May he be shaken out   and have nothing! ”

ngiemboon: Tà fó lyɛ̌ʼ gie fùɔ la lɔgɔ wɔ́ɔn ńgÿo ngúmnɔ̀ɔn tsɛ̀ɛ ngwòŋ pà Yúndà, tà fóo na ngùʼu láʼ mbɔ́ɔntè móm mbʉ́a ńgʉa ńkúu na ngùʼ mbɔ́ɔntè ntsɔ̀b pʉ́a né móm ntá na fʉ̀ʼ gie fùɔ Atasesɛ̂ɛ la ne sáʼa láʼ, é gÿo ngùʼ ntsɔ̀b pʉ́a né legém, mèŋ mbɔɔ mefɛ̌ pɔ́ɔn, peg la te láʼ ńjÿó pì na nkáb gie mé lɔ́ɔn ńnáa mbwó ngúmnɔ̀ɔn wɔ́.
en: Furthermore, from the day King Artaxerxes   appointed me to be their governor in the land of Judah #— #from the twentieth year until his thirty-second year, twelve years  # 5:14 Neh 13:6  #— #I and my associates never ate from the food allotted to the governor.

ngiemboon: N da gwaa tó yɔ́ɔn mbà mendùŋmvfò ngúmnɔ̀ɔn lɔ́ɔn ńnɔʼɔ ncwò pʉ̀a, ńkẅé mmó mpfɛ̌ mbɔɔ melùʼ ńgÿo nkáb pàg móm lekùɔ. Mbɔɔ kwàʼ megàŋafàʼ pɔ́b la gíŋe ńgwɔ́ nzèm láʼ, ńgwɔ́ pɔ́ kékáŋ, tá ńgʉa na mèŋ, mbà n da lɔgɔ lepɔ́g Ssé, n te gÿo páʼ pɔ́b wɔ́.
en: The governors   who preceded me had heavily burdened the people, taking from them food and wine as well as a pound  # 5:15 Lit 40 shekels of silver. Their subordinates also oppressed the people, but because of the fear of God, I didn’t do this.  # 5:15 Lv 25:36

ngiemboon: Tà ńcʉ́ʼ púʼu, mbà n da cʉ́ʼʉ léfaʼa na tʉ̂ankáʼ ŋwɛ́, éfaʼ tà ńnéŋe twó, peg ka te jú nkáʼ nyìŋ wɔ́, mbɔɔ megàŋafàʼ pɔ́ɔn ntsèm piŋ ḿbú ńcúʼte faʼ pɔ́ fàʼ gie á la ne ńdíe wɔ́b.
en: Instead, I devoted myself to the construction of this wall,   and all my subordinates were gathered there for the work. We didn’t buy any land.  # 5:16 Neh 5:3,7,11

ngiemboon: Epʉ̀a pie é lɔ́ɔn ḿbumte ndá mèŋ, peg lâ pɔ̌ jÿó shúm léjÿó, é laa pʉ̀a nkÿo né móm ntʉ̂a; é laa púʼu ńgwɔ́ pà Yúndà ńgÿo pasáʼntsaŋ, té sáŋ pʉ̀a pie é lɔ́ɔn fóo tsɛ̀ɛ meláʼ mie é kéle wég.
en: There were 150 Jews and officials, as well as guests from the surrounding nations at my table.

ngiemboon: Mé lɔ́ɔn ńgee na lyɛʼɛ́ láʼ, ńzẅé tàʼ fòŋ, ḿbiŋe ńgee nùɔ menjʉ̀njÿò ńtyɛ́te menjʉ̀njÿò ntɔgɔ́ mie é tẅɛ, tá ńgÿo ngáb; ḿbiŋ ńnyɛte melùʼ mie mé ge nú nú lyɛ̌ʼ legém. Tà mbɔɔ púʼu, n da te láʼ ńzɛ́te tsɔ́ mmó gie ngwɔ́ mé náa mbwó mèŋ ngúmnɔ̀ɔn wɔ́, á nue mmó gie mé la ne ńzɛ́te, á la ne ńzɛɛ pɔ́ pʉ̀a pɔ́ɔn.
en: Each   day, one ox, six choice sheep, and some fowl were prepared for me. An abundance of all kinds of wine was provided every ten days.  # 5:18 1Kg 4:22–23 But I didn’t demand the food allotted to the governor, because the burden on the people was so heavy.

ngiemboon: «E Ssé yɔ̀ɔn, te lege wɔ́ɔn ńtí nò mbòŋo gie n gÿǒ na pʉ̀a láʼ pɔɔn.»
en: Remember me favorably, my God, for all that I have done for this people.
